questions.text:
One day after undergoing an open colectomy, a 65-year-old man with colon cancer experiences shivers. The procedure was originally scheduled to be done laparoscopically, but it was converted because of persistent bleeding. The surgery was uneventful. Five years ago, he underwent renal transplantation because of cystic disease and has been taking prednisolone since then. He has a history of allergy to sulfonamides. He appears acutely ill. His temperature is 39.2°C (102.5°F), pulse is 120/min, respirations are 23/min, and blood pressure is 90/62 mm Hg. Abdominal examination shows a midline incision extending from the xiphisternum to the pubic symphysis. There is a 5-cm (2-in) area of purplish discoloration near the margin of the incision in the lower abdomen. Palpation of the abdomen produces severe pain and crackling sounds are heard. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
12.5 g/dL 


Leukocyte count
18,600/mm3


Platelet count
228,000/mm3



Erythrocyte sedimentation rate
120 mm/h


Serum



 Na+

134 mEq/L 


 K+

3.5 mEq/L 


 Cl-

98 mEq/L 


 HCO3-

22 mEq/L 


 Glucose
200 mg/dL 


 Urea nitrogen
60 mg/dL 


 Creatinine
3.2 mg/dL 


 Creatine kinase

750 U/L 


Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: X-ray of the abdomen and pelvis

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A postoperative x-ray of the abdomen and pelvis is commonly done if intestinal perforation is suspected. This patient has no nausea, vomiting, abdominal distention, or signs of peritonitis to suggest intestinal perforation. Imaging modalities can, however, help in equivocal cases of necrotizing fasciitis. Plain x-ray can visualize subcutaneous gas (the source of the crackling sounds in this patient), but this is a specific, not a sensitive finding (positive in fewer than 25% of cases) and absence of gas does not exclude necrotizing fasciitis. Awaiting imaging in this man would delay treatment required for necrotizing fasciitis.

B) INCORRECT:

Vacuum-assisted closure (VAC) devices are commonly used for pressure sores, chronic and complex wounds, and skin grafts. VAC is not commonly used with devitalized soft tissue or wounds with inadequate perfusion because VAC can cause or worsen ischemia. Although VAC is not the primary treatment for necrotizing fasciitis, it may be considered as an adjunct therapy at a later stage for effective wound cleaning and exudate removal.

C) CORRECT:

Necrotizing soft tissue infections (NSTIs) are considered a medical emergency as these infections can lead to sepsis and septic shock. Surgical exploration with debridement is the treatment of choice for NSTIs. This procedure also confirms the diagnosis and should be prioritized before other diagnostic steps, such as imaging. After extensive exploration of the affected area and removal of necrotic tissue, deep tissue samples should be obtained for Gram staining, cultures, and histopathology. Surgical reexploration of the affected area every 12–36 hours may be needed to confirm the absence of necrotic tissue.

In addition, all patients with clinically suspected NSTI should receive systemic, broad-spectrum antibiotic therapy immediately after blood cultures have been obtained. Supportive therapy (e.g., fluid resuscitation, oxygen therapy) should be adapted according to the patient's hemodynamic parameters.

D) INCORRECT:

Cefuroxime is a second-generation cephalosporin effective against many bacterial infections while metronidazole is effective against anaerobic infections. However, oral antibiotic therapy has no role in the management of necrotizing soft tissue infection (NSTI). Furthermore, the typical antibiotic regimen for NSTI with systemic signs typically consists of IV vancomycin and piperacillin/tazobactam.

E) INCORRECT:

Postoperative CT scan of the abdomen can be used to diagnose any intra-abdominal pathology such as a collection. A post-operative collection commonly manifests with fever and abdominal pain around 4–5 days rather than 1 day after surgery and does not cause purplish discoloration of the skin. CT scan could also be used if the diagnosis for this patient's fever and chills was unknown or the diagnosis of necrotizing fasciitis was equivocal. However, awaiting imaging would only delay the treatment required for this patient's necrotizing fasciitis.

F) INCORRECT:

Clindamycin is commonly used to treat skin infections like cellulitis, erysipelas, or bone infections. While intravenous clindamycin can be used to treat necrotizing fasciitis, it is not used as monotherapy but rather in combination with beta-lactamase inhibitors and vancomycin or linezolid. Since ischemia and hypoxia compromise the adequate delivery of antibiotics to the infection site, conservative treatment with antibiotics alone has little value in the management of necrotizing fasciitis.
questions.hint: This man with hyperglycemia and postoperative fever one day after undergoing open colectomy has purplish discoloration of the margins of his surgical incision along with severe tenderness to palpation and crackling sounds indicating necrotizing fasciitis. The raised blood urea and creatinine levels may indicate acute kidney injury, and a qSOFA score of 2 (respiratory rate > 22/min and systolic blood pressure < 100 mm Hg) suggests early sepsis.

questions.text: Two hours after admission to the intensive care unit, a 56-year-old man with necrotizing pancreatitis develops profound hypotension. His blood pressure is 80/50 mm Hg and he is started on vasopressors. A central venous access line is placed. Which of the following is most likely to decrease the risk of complications from central venous catheter placement?

choices.text: Initiation of periprocedural systemic antibiotic prophylaxis
Replacement of the central venous line every 7-10 days
Preparation of the patient's skin with chlorhexidine and alcohol
Placement of the central venous line in the femoral vein

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Anticoagulation is not routinely performed after central venous line placement to reduce the risk of catheter-related complications. Flushing of the line with heparin should only be considered in patients who require long-term central venous access.

B) INCORRECT:

Periprocedural systemic antibiotic prophylaxis is not routinely performed during CVL insertion to reduce catheter colonization or CLABSI. Flushing of the line with antibiotics is generally only considered in patients who require long-term central venous access or who are immune suppressed.

C) INCORRECT:

Routine replacement of CVL every 7–10 days is not recommended because it does not reduce the risk of CLABSI and unnecessarily exposes the patient to additional procedures. Central lines should be inserted and accessed only when absolutely necessary and then removed as soon as possible. Hospitalized patients with CVLs should be assessed daily to determine whether or not the line can be removed.

D) CORRECT:

Proper hand hygiene and preparing the patient's skin with chlorhexidine and alcohol is the most effective strategy in decreasing the risk of infection (e.g., CLABSI) from CVL placement. Chlorhexidine has proven superior to iodine-based compounds for antisepsis.

E) INCORRECT:

Placing the CVL in the femoral vein would not reduce complications, as femoral lines carry an increased risk of CLABSI due to their location. The preferred sites for CVL insertion are the subclavian and internal jugular veins. While the subclavian site minimizes the risk of infection, it is associated with a higher rate of iatrogenic pneumothorax. The internal jugular site, on the other hand, is associated with a greater risk of infection but a lower risk of pneumothorax.
questions.hint: Precautions must be taken when placing central venous catheters to prevent central-line associated bloodstream infections (CLABSI).

questions.text: A 69-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of a 2-day history of cough and dyspnea. The cough is productive of small amounts of green phlegm. She has stage IV colon cancer and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. Her medications include 5-fluorouracil, leucovorin, a fluticasone-salmeterol inhaler, and a tiotropium bromide inhaler. Her temperature is 39°C (102.2°F), pulse is 107/min, respirations are 31/min, and blood pressure is 89/68 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 87%. Pulmonary examination shows diffuse crackles and rhonchi. An x-ray of the chest shows a left upper-lobe infiltrate of the lung. Two sets of blood cultures are obtained. Endotracheal aspirate Gram stain shows gram-negative rods that are oxidase-positive. Two large bore cannulas are inserted and intravenous fluids are administered. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Clarithromycin and amoxicillin-clavulanate are used in the outpatient treatment of CAP patients with comorbidities. Although this patient has COPD, this regimen is not effective against P. aeruginosa and is therefore not appropriate in this patient.

B) INCORRECT:

Combination therapy with ceftriaxone and azithromycin is used to treat severe CAP that requires admission to the ICU (e.g., acute respiratory failure, septic shock). Although this patient has CAP and may require admission to the ICU, the most likely causative organism in this patient is P. aeruginosa, against which ceftriaxone and azithromycin are not effective.

C) CORRECT:

Cefepime and levofloxacin are the first-line treatment for patients with CAP when there is a strong suspicion of P. aeruginosa infection. Other treatment options for CAP with P. aeruginosa include piperacillin/tazobactam, meropenem, or imipenem plus a fluoroquinolone. An aminoglycoside may be added as well.

D) INCORRECT:

Vancomycin only provides coverage against gram-positive organisms and is mainly used to treat methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA). This patient most likely has an infection with P. aeruginosa, a gram-negative rod, against which vancomycin is ineffective.

E) INCORRECT:

Colistin is an antibiotic of last resort that is used to treat multidrug-resistant gram-negative bacteria (MDRGN). Risk factors for MDRGN include prior antibiotic use, lengthy hospital stays, and age > 70 years. Although infection with a multidrug-resistant P. aeruginosa strain cannot be ruled out at this point, the patient should first be started on the first-line empiric treatment for CAP with P. aeruginosa infection. An antibiotic sensitivity test should be conducted before considering an antibiotic of last resort.
questions.hint: Fever, productive cough, crackles, and an infiltrate on chest x-ray are consistent with community-acquired pneumonia (CAP). Given this patient's history of COPD, possible immunosuppression due to chemotherapy, greenish sputum, and gram-negative, oxidase-positive rods, Pseudomonas aeruginosa is the most likely causative organism.

questions.text: Five days after undergoing right hemicolectomy for colon cancer, a 62-year-old man has fever, abdominal pain, nausea, and urinary frequency. The surgery was uncomplicated. An indwelling urinary catheter was placed intraoperatively. His temperature is 39.4°C (102.9°F), pulse is 91/min, and blood pressure is 118/83 mm Hg. There is tenderness to palpation of the costovertebral angle. The urine collected in the catheter bag appears cloudy. Which of the following measures is most likely to have prevented this patient's current condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although it has been shown that urinary antiseptics such as methenamine can have a beneficial effect in the prevention of catheter-associated urinary tract infections, the evidence is limited, and the use of urinary antiseptics is not generally recommended.

B) CORRECT:

The most effective measures for the prevention of catheter-associated urinary tract infections (UTIs) are avoidance of unnecessary catheterization, sterile technique during catheter placement, and early removal of urinary catheters when they are no longer indicated; patients undergoing surgery not involving the urinary tract should have their catheters removed as soon as possible (preferably within 24 hours postoperatively).

C) INCORRECT:

Antimicrobial prophylaxis has not been proven to have a beneficial effect in the prevention of catheter-associated urinary tract infections. Furthermore, excessive use of prophylactic antibiotics should be avoided, because it may lead to the development of drug-resistant pathogens. Intravenous antimicrobial prophylaxis administered shortly before surgery, on the other hand, is an effective intervention for the prevention of surgical site infections.

D) INCORRECT:

Periurethral care with soap and water is considered adequate maintenance care for an indwelling catheter. However, it has not been proven to have a beneficial effect in the prevention of catheter-associated urinary tract infections. Likewise, the use of antiseptics for cleaning the meatal area, either before or after catheter placement, has not been shown to prevent infections and may lead to the development of drug-resistant pathogens.

E) INCORRECT:

Although some recent studies have shown that bladder irrigation with antibiotics, antiseptics, or saline solutions can have a beneficial effect in the prevention of catheter-associated urinary tract infections, this method is generally not recommended because the evidence is limited. Furthermore, antimicrobial bladder irrigation may lead to the development of drug-resistant pathogens.

F) INCORRECT:

Although there may be a temporary reduction in the number of bacteria found in the urine following the changing of a catheter, daily catheter replacement has not been proven to have a beneficial effect in the prevention of catheter-associated urinary tract infections. Therefore, indwelling catheters should not be replaced routinely as long as the urinary flow appears adequate.
questions.hint: This patient's fever, abdominal pain, nausea, urinary frequency, flank pain, and cloudy urine suggest pyelonephritis.

questions.text: Four days after an operation for a perforated gastric ulcer, a hospitalized 68-year-old woman develops decreased urinary output, hyperkalemia, and severe uremia. A tunneled central venous catheter is placed in the subclavian vein and renal replacement therapy is initiated. Ten days later, the patient develops fever and hypotension. Her temperature is 39.4°C (102.9°F), pulse is 108/min, and blood pressure is 86/50 mm Hg. Cardiac examination shows an S3 gallop. Pulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. The skin overlying the catheter appears well perfused, with no tenderness to palpation and no purulent discharge. Samples for blood culture are drawn simultaneously from the central line and a peripheral vein. Blood cultures from the central line grow nonlactose fermenting, gram-negative bacilli. Three hours later, blood cultures from the peripheral venipuncture grow the same bacteria. Which of the following is the most effective measure to reduce the incidence of this patient's current infection?

choices.text: Maintenance of negative ambient air pressure in intensive care units
Implementation of real-time feedback loops for hand hygiene compliance
Placement of central venous catheters in the femoral rather than subclavian vein
Administration of ceftazidime through the introducer needle before passing the guide wire
Application of mupirocin ointment to the anterior nares of critically ill patients

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Maintenance of negative ambient air pressure is an example of an airborne precaution, which is effective in preventing in-hospital airborne transmission of diseases such as tuberculosis, measles, or varicella. P. aeruginosa is spread via contact transmission; standard precautions and contact precautions are effective in preventing nosocomial P. aeruginosa infections but airborne precautions are not. Moreover, in intensive care units, especially ones caring for immunosuppressed patients, a protective environment with a positive rather than negative ambient air pressure is usually maintained (neutropenic precautions).

B) CORRECT:

The most common mechanism for CLABSI is microbial spread (via surface motility and/or biofilm formation) to the CVC exit site from the patient's skin and/or the CVC hub. The hands of health care providers (HCPs) are often colonized by pathogens, resulting in HCPs cross-contaminating patients, other HCPs, and inanimate objects (leading to contact transmission), thereby facilitating nosocomial infections. Strict adherence to hand hygiene measures is necessary to prevent nosocomial infections such as CLABSI. Despite high numbers of hand hygiene stations and visual reminders at hospitals, the level of hand hygiene compliance among HCPs remains low because of lapses (due to work overload), poor situational awareness, and/or intolerance or aversion to certain disinfectants. An effective measure to increase compliance is a real-time feedback loop, in which hand hygiene observers or electronic hand hygiene systems monitor compliance and provide immediate feedback (e.g., verbal feedback on improper technique, data visualization of each hospital floor's hand hygiene process measures). Additional steps to increase hand hygiene compliance include staff training and providing alcohol-based foam rubs (which are quicker to use, more effective, and no more irritating to the skin than soap and water) at hand hygiene stations.

CLABSI bundles (a collection of measures to prevent CLABSI) include proper site identification and technique for CVC insertion (e.g., avoiding the femoral region whenever possible), standardized checklists, and aseptic precautions (e.g., sterile glove use, disinfection with chlorhexidine) for CVC insertion as well as CVC site care, CVC removal as soon as possible, and champions-led rounding. These measures are important adjuncts but not substitutes for hand hygiene.
Image Description:

Use the elbow to dispense disinfectant into the hand, then rub it with the other hand for ∼ 30 seconds. If the hands become dry before this time, dispense more disinfectant.

1. To cover palms, dorsal hands, and web spaces: palm-to-palm and dorsal hands-to-palm, both with fingers together and with fingers interlocked

2. To cover fingers and fingertips: dorsal fingers to opposite palm with fingers interlocked, and rotation of clasped fingers in opposite palm

3. To cover thumbs: rotation of thumb in opposite palm

C) INCORRECT:

When compared with the subclavian vein, placement of CVCs in the femoral vein has a lower risk of certain insertion-related complications (e.g., pneumothorax, hematomas, vein stenosis) but a higher risk of CLABSI. Moreover, femoral CVCs are more likely to result in CLABSIs with gram-negative bacilli and Candida because the groin area has high levels of colonization by these microbes (due to factors such as moisture in intertriginous areas and proximity to the anogenital region) and is harder to keep clean. Femoral CVCs should be avoided.

D) INCORRECT:

Ceftazidime is an antibiotic that is effective against P. aeruginosa, and antibiotic lock therapy (e.g., with ceftazidime-heparin solutions) can be used selectively for the secondary prevention of CLABSI (e.g., for patients like this one receiving hemodialysis via tunneled catheters). However, antibiotics are ineffective in the primary prevention of CLABSI and do not have a role before or during CVC insertion (e.g., through the introducer needle). Antibiotics should only be used if indicated and, in such cases, the principle of antibiotic stewardship should be followed.

E) INCORRECT:

Staphylococcus aureus, which causes nosocomial infections including CLABSI, often colonizes the anterior nares, and nasal application of mupirocin ointment is recommended for critically ill patients as part of the universal decolonization protocol to prevent methicillin-resistant S. aureus infection. However, S. aureus is a gram-positive coccus whereas this patient has a P. aeruginosa infection. P. aeruginosa rarely colonizes the upper airways (e.g., in patients with cystic fibrosis) and mupirocin is typically ineffective against Pseudomonas spp.
questions.hint: The onset of fever and hemodynamic instability ≥ 48 hours after the insertion of a central venous catheter (CVC) and the growth of the same organism on blood cultures from the CVC and a peripheral vein with a differential time to positivity ≥ 120 minutes indicate a central-line associated bloodstream infection (CLABSI), even if the CVC's exit site does not show evidence of infection (e.g., tenderness, purulence). Pseudomonas aeruginosa is a nonlactose fermenting, gram-negative bacillus that causes CLABSI.

questions.text: A 76-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with fever, chills, and right flank pain for two days. She was recently discharged from a skilled nursing facility after a 3-week stay following a hip fracture. Her medical history includes type 2 diabetes mellitus, chronic kidney disease, and hypertension. Vital signs are BP, 128/74; P, 102; R, 20; T, 38.9°C (102.0°F). Examination shows right costovertebral angle tenderness. Laboratory testing shows WBC 17,600/mm³, creatinine 1.8 mg/dL, and positive leukocyte esterase, nitrites, and many WBCs on urinalysis. Which of the following empiric antibiotic regimens is most appropriate?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

TMP-SMX can be used as empiric therapy for uncomplicated pyelonephritis when susceptibility is known. It is not used in patients with risk factors for multidrug-resistant organism.

B) INCORRECT:

Daptomycin is used as part of combination therapy in pyelonephritis when MRSA or VRE coverage is needed. It is not appropriate as monotherapy for pyelonephritis, as gram-negative bacteria are the predominant cause of urinary tract infections and daptomycin has no activity against these organisms.

C) CORRECT:

Correct – This patient has complicated pyelonephritis with risk factors for multidrug-resistant gram-negative organisms, including age ≥ 65 years and recent long-term care facility stay. Piperacillin-tazobactam provides appropriate broad-spectrum coverage for patients with risk factors for multidrug-resistant pathogens.

D) INCORRECT:

Fluoroquinolones are used in the treatment of pyelonephritis in patients who are not severely ill and who have no risk factors for multidrug-resistant pathogens. They are not appropriate in patients with risk factors for multidrug-resistant pathogens.

E) INCORRECT:

While other cephalosporins are appropriate for complicated pyelonephritis in patients with risk factors for multidrug-resistant pathogens, cefotaxime should only be used empirically when these risk factors are absent. This patient's age and recent long-term care facility stay require broader empiric coverage.

questions.text: A 73-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with cramping abdominal pain and watery diarrhea. She was discharged 5 days ago after a 10-day hospitalization for pneumonia treated with broad-spectrum antibiotics. She reports having 8 loose stools in the past 24 hours. Vital signs are BP, 110/70; P, 105; T, 38.2°C (100.8°F). Laboratory studies show WBC 18,500/mm³ and creatinine 1.2 mg/dL. Which of the following is he most appropriate empiric antibiotic regimen?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Rifaximin is used for recurrent C. difficile infection following vancomycin therapy, not as initial therapy.

B) CORRECT:

Correct – This patient has severe C. difficile infection based on leukocytosis ≥ 15,000/mm³ with typical risk factors including recent hospitalization and broad-spectrum antibiotic exposure. Oral fidaxomicin is first-line therapy for severe CDI and is preferred over vancomycin due to higher clinical response rates and lower recurrence rates. If fidaxomicin is unavailable, oral vancomycin is an appropriate alternative.

C) INCORRECT:

The combination of vancomycin plus metronidazole is reserved for fulminant CDI (either WBC ≥ 15,000 cells/mm3 or serum creatinine ≥ 1.5 mg/dL plus either hypotension, shock, ileus, or toxic megacolon). This patient lacks criteria for fulminant disease and requires monotherapy with first-line agents.

D) INCORRECT:

Ampicillin/sulbactam is used for intraabdominal infections but is not effective against C. difficile. This beta-lactam antibiotic could potentially worsen CDI by further disrupting normal intestinal flora.

E) INCORRECT:

Oral metronidazole is second-line therapy for patients with nonsevere CDI when first-line agents are unavailable or inappropriate (e.g., due to allergy). It is not the most appropriate choice in this patient.

questions.text: A 72-year-old man with diabetes mellitus presents with fever, productive cough, and oxygen saturation of 88% on room air. He was discharged from the hospital 10 days ago following a prolonged stay for acute respiratory failure requiring mechanical ventilation. Chest x-ray shows bilateral lower lobe infiltrates. Vital signs are BP, 95/60; P, 110; T, 38.9°C (102.0°F). What is the most appropriate initial antibiotic therapy?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Patients with hospital-acquired pneumonia are at risk for infection with a multidrug-resistant gram-negative organism and/or methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA). Ampicillin/sulbactam has limited activity against multidrug-resistant gram-negative bacteria commonly encountered in hospital-acquired pneumonia and does not cover MRSA. Doxycycline may have activity against community-acquired MRSA, but it is not an antibiotic of choice for hospital-acquired MRSA.

B) CORRECT:

Correct -- This patient has several risk factors for acquiring a multidrug-resistant organism infection (e.g., age > 70 years, diabetes mellitus, recent prolonged hospitalization with mechanical ventilation, and hospital discharge within 90 days). Cefepime for broad-spectrum antipseudomonal coverage and vancomycin for coverage of methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) provide adequate empiric therapy for hospital-acquired pneumonia in most patients with MRSA risk factors.

C) INCORRECT:

Empiric ceftriaxone and azithromycin is appropriate for community-acquired pneumonia, but this regimen lacks adequate coverage for multidrug-resistant gram-negative organisms and methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus that are common causes of hospital-acquired pneumonia.

D) INCORRECT:

While linezolid provides coverage for methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus, levofloxacin monotherapy is insufficient for the empiric treatment of patients with hospital-acquired pneumonia and risk factors for multidrug-resistant organisms. This drug combination has inadequate coverage for multidrug-resistant gram-negative organisms such as Pseudomonas aeruginosa.

E) INCORRECT:

Meropenem provides excellent gram-negative coverage, including those with multidrug resistance, but lacks coverage for methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA). Given this patient's risk factors for MRSA colonization, combination therapy with an anti-MRSA agent is indicated for empiric treatment.

questions.text: Ten days after the placement of a tunneled central venous catheter in the subclavian vein, a hospitalized 68-year-old woman develops fever and hypotension. Samples for blood culture are drawn simultaneously from the central line and a peripheral vein. Blood cultures from the central line grow nonlactose fermenting, gram-negative bacilli. Three hours later, blood cultures from the peripheral venipuncture grow the same bacteria. Which of the following is the most effective measure to reduce the incidence of this patient's current infection?

choices.text: Administration of ceftazidime through the introducer needle before passing the guide wire.
Maintenance of negative ambient air pressure in intensive care units.
Application of mupirocin ointment to the anterior nares of critically ill patients.
Placement of central venous catheters in the femoral rather than subclavian vein.
Implementation of real-time feedback loops for hand hygiene compliance.

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Ceftazidime is an antibiotic that is effective against P. aeruginosa, and antibiotic lock therapy (e.g., with ceftazidime-heparin solutions) can be used selectively for the secondary prevention of CLABSI. However, antibiotics are ineffective in the primary prevention of CLABSI and do not have a role before or during CVC insertion (e.g., through the introducer needle). Antibiotics should only be used if indicated and, in such cases, the principle of antibiotic stewardship should be followed.

B) INCORRECT:

Maintenance of negative ambient air pressure is an example of an airborne precaution, which is effective in preventing in-hospital airborne transmission of diseases such as tuberculosis, measles, or varicella. P. aeruginosa is spread via contact transmission; standard precautions and contact precautions are effective in preventing nosocomial P. aeruginosa infections but airborne precautions are not. Moreover, in intensive care units, especially ones caring for immunosuppressed patients, a protective environment with a positive rather than negative ambient air pressure is usually maintained (neutropenic precautions).

C) INCORRECT:

Staphylococcus aureus, which causes nosocomial infections including CLABSI, often colonizes the anterior nares, and nasal application of mupirocin ointment is recommended for critically ill patients as part of the universal decolonization protocol to prevent methicillin-resistant S. aureus infection. However, S. aureus is a gram-positive coccus whereas this patient has a P. aeruginosa infection. P. aeruginosa rarely colonizes the upper airways (e.g., in patients with cystic fibrosis) and mupirocin is typically ineffective against Pseudomonas spp.

D) INCORRECT:

When compared with the subclavian vein, placement of CVCs in the femoral vein has a lower risk of certain insertion-related complications (e.g., pneumothorax, hematomas, vein stenosis) but a higher risk of CLABSI. Moreover, femoral CVCs are more likely to result in CLABSIs with gram-negative bacilli and Candida because the groin area has high levels of colonization by these microbes (due to factors such as moisture in intertriginous areas and proximity to the anogenital region) and is harder to keep clean. Femoral CVCs should be avoided.

E) CORRECT:

The most common mechanism for CLABSI is microbial spread (via surface motility and/or biofilm formation) to the CVC exit site from the patient's skin and/or the CVC hub. The hands of health care providers (HCPs) are often colonized by pathogens, resulting in HCPs cross-contaminating patients, other HCPs, and inanimate objects (leading to contact transmission), thereby facilitating nosocomial infections. Strict adherence to hand hygiene measures is necessary to prevent nosocomial infections such as CLABSI. Despite high numbers of hand hygiene stations and visual reminders at hospitals, the level of hand hygiene compliance among HCPs remains low because of lapses (due to work overload), poor situational awareness, and/or intolerance or aversion to certain disinfectants. An effective measure to increase compliance is a real-time feedback loop, in which hand hygiene observers or electronic hand hygiene systems monitor compliance and provide immediate feedback (e.g., verbal feedback on improper technique, data visualization of each hospital floor's hand hygiene process measures). Additional steps to increase hand hygiene compliance include staff training and providing alcohol-based foam rubs (which are quicker to use, more effective, and no more irritating to the skin than soap and water) at hand hygiene stations.

CLABSI bundles (a collection of measures to prevent CLABSI) include proper site identification and technique for CVC insertion (e.g., avoiding the femoral region whenever possible), standardized checklists, and aseptic precautions (e.g., sterile glove use, disinfection with chlorhexidine) for CVC insertion as well as CVC site care, CVC removal as soon as possible, and champions-led rounding. These measures are important adjuncts but not substitutes for hand hygiene.

Key learning point: Strict hand hygiene with real-time compliance feedback is the most effective strategy to prevent central-line-associated bloodstream infections.
Image Description:

Use the elbow to dispense disinfectant into the hand, then rub it with the other hand for ∼ 30 seconds. If the hands become dry before this time, dispense more disinfectant.

1. To cover palms, dorsal hands, and web spaces: palm-to-palm and dorsal hands-to-palm, both with fingers together and with fingers interlocked

2. To cover fingers and fingertips: dorsal fingers to opposite palm with fingers interlocked, and rotation of clasped fingers in opposite palm

3. To cover thumbs: rotation of thumb in opposite palm
questions.hint: The onset of fever and hemodynamic instability ≥ 48 hours after the insertion of a central venous catheter (CVC) and the growth of the same organism on blood cultures from the CVC and a peripheral vein with a differential time to positivity ≥ 120 minutes indicate a central-line associated bloodstream infection (CLABSI). Pseudomonas aeruginosa is a nonlactose fermenting, gram-negative bacillus that causes CLABSI.
